lessonActivities.title: Future Perfect – Actions Finished Before a Future Point!
lessonActivities.content:
Imagine looking back from the future at something already done. That’s Future Perfect! When you say “By 2030, I will have visited 50 countries,” you’re using it!

Future Perfect = will have / be going to have + past participle

Think of it like a time machine: you jump to a future moment and look back at completed actions.

  • By next June → I will have finished my degree
  • When you arrive → we will have eaten

Fun fact: 'will' and 'be going to' forms mean almost the same here!
examples: By the time he gets home, she will have cleaned the house.
I will have learned 1000 words by December.
functions: Talking about achievements before a future time
lessonActivities.tips: Quick Rule: Use by / by the time + present simple in the time clause!

lessonActivities.title: Future Perfect Continuous – How Long Something Will Have Been Happening
lessonActivities.content:
Now we add duration! Future Perfect Continuous shows how long an action will have been in progress up to a future point.

Formation: will have been / be going to have been + verb-ing

When to use:

  1. Duration up to a future moment → By July, I will have been living here for 10 years
  2. Cause of a future state → He’ll be tired because he will have been working all night

Fun fact: English speakers often prefer Future Continuous without duration — but with for/since, we need Perfect Continuous!
examples: By Friday, we will have been driving for 12 hours.
She is going to have been studying English for 5 years when she graduates.
lessonActivities.tips: Memory trick: If you can add 'for 3 years' or 'since 2020' → Future Perfect Continuous!

lessonActivities.title: Future Perfect vs Future Perfect Continuous – The Big Difference!
lessonActivities.content:
Here’s the key distinction!

Future PerfectFuture Perfect Continuous
Focus on completion
I will have finished the report.		Focus on duration
I will have been working on the report for 6 hours.
Result mattersProcess and time spent matters

Common mistake: Using continuous with stative verbs → Ned will have had his license (not been having!)
examples: He will be tired because he will have been jogging. (duration) ≠ He will have run 10 km. (completion)
lessonActivities.tips: Pro tip: No duration word (for/since) → usually just Future Continuous, not Perfect Continuous!

lessonActivities.title: The Golden Rule: NO Future in Time Clauses!
lessonActivities.content:
Biggest mistake ever! In time clauses (when, by the time, before, after…), NEVER use will/won’t!

Wrong: When I will finish → Correct: When I finish / have finished

With Future Perfect, use Present Perfect in the time clause:

  • By the time you arrive, I will have cooked dinner
  • As soon as she has saved enough, she’ll buy a car

Fun fact: This rule applies to ALL future tenses!
examples: I’ll call you when I have arrived.
She won’t leave until she has seen the doctor.
lessonActivities.tips: Never forget: Time clause = present tenses only!

writingActivities.question: Write 6–8 sentences about your life goals. Use Future Perfect at least 4 times with 'by the time / by + date'.
writingActivities.hint: Example: By the time I’m 40, I will have visited 30 countries.
sentenceStarters: By the time I retire, ___ .

writingActivities.question: Write about a very busy week in the future. Use Future Perfect Continuous at least 3 times to show duration.
writingActivities.hint: Example: By Friday, I will have been working non-stop for two weeks!
sentenceStarters: Next month, I will have been ___ .
By the end of the term, ___ .

writingActivities.question: Write a short paragraph predicting someone's future state and explain why (cause-effect). Use both tenses.
writingActivities.hint: Example: She’ll be fluent because she will have been studying for years.
sentenceStarters: He will be exhausted because ___ .
By then, she ___ .

writingActivities.question: Imagine it’s the year 2040. Write 6–8 sentences about what you will have achieved in your career and personal life. Use Future Perfect at least 5 times.
writingActivities.hint: Start with: By 2040, I will have… / By the time I’m 50, I will have…
sentenceStarters: By 2040, I will have ___ .
By the time I reach 50, I will have ___ .

writingActivities.question: Describe a very long, intense project (real or imaginary) you will finish soon. Use Future Perfect Continuous at least 4 times to show duration and effort.
writingActivities.hint: Example: By the time I submit it, I will have been researching for 18 months straight!
sentenceStarters: By the deadline, I will have been ___ .
When I finally finish, I will have been ___ for ___ .

writingActivities.question: Write about someone you know (or invent a person) who will be extremely tired/experienced/fluent in the future. Use both Future Perfect and Future Perfect Continuous + 'because' at least twice.
writingActivities.hint: Example: He’ll be exhausted because he will have been training 8 hours a day, and he’ll be in perfect shape because he will have followed the program for a whole year.
sentenceStarters: She will be completely fluent because ___ .
He will be totally exhausted because ___ .

writingActivities.question: Write a short letter to your future self (to be opened in 10 years). Use Future Perfect at least 4 times and Future Perfect Continuous at least 2 times.
writingActivities.hint: Dear Future Me… By then, I hope I will have… and I will have been…
sentenceStarters: Dear Future Me, by 2035 I will have ___ .
I will have been living/working/studying ___ for ___ years.

writingActivities.question: Predict your family’s or friends’ achievements in the next 5–15 years. Use Future Perfect at least 5 times with different subjects (my brother, my parents, my best friend…)
writingActivities.hint: Example: My sister will have graduated from medical school by 2028.
sentenceStarters: My brother will have ___ by the time he’s 30.
By 2030, my parents will have ___ .

writingActivities.question: Write about a world-changing invention or event that will happen soon. Use Future Perfect Continuous to show long preparation (scientists, researchers…) and Future Perfect for the final result.
writingActivities.hint: Example: By the time the mission launches, scientists will have been developing the technology for over 20 years and finally will have created sustainable fusion energy.
sentenceStarters: By the time the new technology ___ , researchers will have been ___ .
Finally, humanity will have ___ after decades of effort.

writingActivities.question: Free writing: Describe your life ‘by this time next decade’. Mix both tenses naturally, include time clauses with present tenses, and avoid any future forms in time clauses.
writingActivities.hint: Challenge: No 'will' in when/by the time/before clauses! Use present or present perfect only.
sentenceStarters: By this time in 2035, ___ .
When I look back, I will have ___ .

gameActivities.question: Achievement completed before a future deadline – what form?
gameActivities.sentence: By the end of this month, I ____ all my exams.
gameActivities.hint: Focus on completion before a future point (Lesson 1: Future Perfect for achievements)

gameActivities.question: Emphasizing how long something will have been going on – duration!
gameActivities.sentence: By next summer, we ____ in Bali for two full years.
gameActivities.hint: Use 'for' + time → duration up to future point (Lesson 2: Future Perfect Continuous)

gameActivities.question: Time clause rule – no future tense here!
gameActivities.sentence: I'll relax as soon as I ____ this project.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause uses present perfect for completion (Lesson 4: No future in time clauses)

gameActivities.question: Result matters: total completed before future moment.
gameActivities.sentence: By 2030, scientists ____ a cure for many diseases.
gameActivities.hint: Focus on the result/achievement (Lesson 1: Future Perfect)

gameActivities.question: Cause of future tiredness – long ongoing activity.
gameActivities.sentence: She'll be exhausted because she ____ all day without a break.
gameActivities.hint: Explaining a future state with duration (Lesson 2: Future Perfect Continuous)

gameActivities.question: Stative verb – cannot use continuous form!
gameActivities.sentence: By next year, they ____ each other for 15 years.
gameActivities.hint: Stative verbs take simple perfect, not continuous (Lesson 3: Avoid stative errors)

gameActivities.question: By the time clause – present simple in the clause!
gameActivities.sentence: By the time the guests ____, we ____ everything ready.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause uses present, main clause future perfect (Lesson 4: Golden rule)

gameActivities.question: Completion vs duration – choose the right emphasis.
gameActivities.sentence: By Friday, the team ____ the report (completion) and ____ on it for weeks (duration).
options: will have finished,will have been working
will have been finishing,will have worked
correctAnswer: will have finished,will have been working
gameActivities.hint: Result + process (Lesson 3: Future Perfect vs Continuous)

gameActivities.question: Long drive – emphasizing time spent.
gameActivities.sentence: By the time we reach Jakarta, we ____ for more than 10 hours.
gameActivities.hint: Focus on duration of ongoing action (Lesson 2: Future Perfect Continuous)

gameActivities.question: Deadline achievement – total completed.
gameActivities.sentence: By the end of today, I ____ 500 emails.
gameActivities.hint: Countable result before future point (Lesson 1: Future Perfect)

gameActivities.question: Time clause with 'when' – present perfect for completion.
gameActivities.sentence: I'll celebrate when I ____ the race.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause uses present perfect (Lesson 4: No future forms)

gameActivities.question: Stative verb duration – simple form only.
gameActivities.sentence: By 2035, my company ____ 20 years old.
gameActivities.hint: Be is stative → simple perfect

gameActivities.question: Ongoing effort explaining future experience.
gameActivities.sentence: He'll be an expert because he ____ English for 10 years by then.
gameActivities.hint: Duration leads to future state (Lesson 2: Cause of future state)

gameActivities.question: By the time – present simple + future perfect continuous.
gameActivities.sentence: By the time the concert ____, fans ____ outside for hours.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause present + duration (Lessons 2 & 4)

gameActivities.question: Lifetime goal completed before a future age.
gameActivities.sentence: By the time I'm 40, I ____ every province in Indonesia.
gameActivities.hint: Achievement by future point (Lesson 1: Future Perfect)

gameActivities.question: After clause – present perfect in time clause.
gameActivities.sentence: We can eat after everyone ____ their hands.
gameActivities.hint: Completion in time clause → present perfect (Lesson 4)

gameActivities.question: Duration of temporary job – continuous needed.
gameActivities.sentence: By December, I ____ at this café for six months.
gameActivities.hint: Temporary ongoing → duration (Lesson 2: Future Perfect Continuous)

gameActivities.question: Two actions: one completed, one duration.
gameActivities.sentence: By next week, the builders ____ the walls and ____ on the house for a month.
options: will have painted,will have been working
will have been painting,will have worked
correctAnswer: will have painted,will have been working
gameActivities.hint: Completion + process (Lesson 3: Contrast)

gameActivities.question: Before clause – present simple in time clause.
gameActivities.sentence: ____ you leave, make sure you ____ the report.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause at start uses present (Lesson 4)

gameActivities.question: Long-term relationship duration – stative but acceptable continuous sometimes, here simple.
gameActivities.sentence: By our anniversary, we ____ married for 25 years.
gameActivities.hint: Duration of state (Lesson 2 & 3)

gameActivities.question: Result focus: total books written.
gameActivities.sentence: By age 50, the author ____ ten novels.
gameActivities.hint: Countable achievements (Lesson 1: Future Perfect)

gameActivities.question: Until clause – present perfect for completion.
gameActivities.sentence: I won't stop until I ____ enough money.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause rule (Lesson 4)

gameActivities.question: Intense duration explaining future soreness.
gameActivities.sentence: My legs will hurt because I ____ mountains all weekend.
gameActivities.hint: Cause of future state with effort (Lesson 2)

gameActivities.question: By the time + present simple + future perfect.
gameActivities.sentence: By the time school ____ tomorrow, the kids ____ homework all evening.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause + long duration (Lessons 2 & 4)

gameActivities.question: Personal milestone – completed travels.
gameActivities.sentence: By retirement, I ____ to over 100 countries.
gameActivities.hint: Lifetime achievement (Lesson 1)

gameActivities.question: As soon as clause – present simple.
gameActivities.sentence: ____ the rain ____, we'll go outside.
gameActivities.hint: Time clause at beginning (Lesson 4)

gameActivities.question: Stative possession – simple perfect.
gameActivities.sentence: By then, she ____ her new car for three months.
gameActivities.hint: Have = stative (Lesson 3)

gameActivities.question: Marathon effort – duration matters.
gameActivities.sentence: By the finish line, the runners ____ for over four hours.
gameActivities.hint: Ongoing effort (Lesson 2: Future Perfect Continuous)

gameActivities.question: When clause – present perfect for prior completion.
gameActivities.sentence: Call me when you ____ reading the book.
gameActivities.hint: Completion before future action (Lesson 4)

gameActivities.question: Grand achievement + long dedication.
gameActivities.sentence: By the opening ceremony, the team ____ the stadium and ____ on it for five years.
options: will have completed,will have been working
will have been completing,will have worked
correctAnswer: will have completed,will have been working
gameActivities.hint: Completion + duration (Lesson 3: Both forms)

quizActivities.question: What structure describes an action completed before a future point?
quizActivities.sentence: By next June, I ____ my degree.
quizActivities.hint: 'By next June' indicates a deadline. Use Future Perfect (will have + past participle) for completion before a future time.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect is used for actions that will be completed before a specific future time. 'By next June' signals a deadline, requiring 'will have finished'.

quizActivities.question: Which form shows duration up to a future moment?
quizActivities.sentence: By July, I ____ here for 10 years.
quizActivities.hint: 'For 10 years' shows duration. When emphasizing how long something will have been happening, use Future Perfect Continuous (will have been + -ing).
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous emphasizes duration up to a future point. 'For 10 years' indicates time spent, so we use 'will have been living'.

quizActivities.question: What verb form completes this time clause correctly?
quizActivities.sentence: By the time you ____, I will have cooked dinner.
quizActivities.hint: Time clauses (by the time, when, before, after) use present tenses, NEVER 'will'. Use present simple here.
quizActivities.explanation: The golden rule: NEVER use 'will' in time clauses! After 'by the time', use present simple or present perfect, not future tenses.

quizActivities.question: What emphasizes the result of completion rather than duration?
quizActivities.sentence: By Friday, we ____ 500 kilometers.
quizActivities.hint: No duration word like 'for' is present, and the focus is on the completed distance (result). Use Future Perfect for completion.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect focuses on completion and results. '500 kilometers' is an achievement/result, not a duration, so use 'will have driven'.

quizActivities.question: Which shows the cause of a future state?
quizActivities.sentence: He'll be tired because he ____ all night.
quizActivities.hint: To explain a future state (tired), show the duration of the activity causing it. Use Future Perfect Continuous.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous explains the cause of a future state. Working continuously all night causes tiredness, so 'will have been working' shows the duration.

quizActivities.question: What's the correct form when talking about achievements?
quizActivities.sentence: By 2030, I ____ 50 countries.
quizActivities.hint: Counting achievements (50 countries) focuses on completion, not duration. Use Future Perfect without continuous.
quizActivities.explanation: '50 countries' is a countable achievement/result. Future Perfect (will have visited) is used for completed actions before a future time.

quizActivities.question: Choose the correct tenses for this complex sentence:
quizActivities.sentence: When she ____ enough money, she ____ a car, and she ____ for it for 5 years by then.
options: has saved / will buy / will have been saving
will have saved / will buy / will have been saving
has saved / buys / will have saved
saves / will buy / is going to be saving
quizActivities.correctAnswer: has saved / will buy / will have been saving
quizActivities.hint: Use present perfect in the time clause ('when'), future simple for the main action, and Future Perfect Continuous for the duration ('for 5 years').
quizActivities.explanation: Time clauses require present perfect (has saved), the main clause uses future simple (will buy), and 'for 5 years' indicates duration requiring Future Perfect Continuous (will have been saving).

quizActivities.question: What's the correct form emphasizing duration with a time marker?
quizActivities.sentence: By Friday, we ____ for 12 hours.
quizActivities.hint: 'For 12 hours' shows duration. Use Future Perfect Continuous (will have been + -ing) when emphasizing how long.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous emphasizes duration. 'For 12 hours' indicates time spent, so 'will have been driving' shows the ongoing process.

quizActivities.question: Which structure correctly expresses completion with 'be going to'?
quizActivities.sentence: She ____ English for 5 years when she graduates.
options: is going to have been studying
quizActivities.correctAnswer: is going to have been studying
quizActivities.hint: 'For 5 years' indicates duration. Both 'will' and 'be going to' work with Future Perfect Continuous. The continuous form emphasizes the duration.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous can use 'be going to have been + -ing'. With 'for 5 years', the continuous form emphasizes duration up to graduation.

quizActivities.question: What form avoids the stative verb error?
quizActivities.sentence: By next year, he ____ his license for a decade.
quizActivities.hint: 'Have' is a stative verb—NEVER use continuous forms with stative verbs. Use Future Perfect only.
quizActivities.explanation: Stative verbs (have, know, be) cannot take continuous forms. Despite 'for a decade' showing duration, use Future Perfect 'will have had', NOT continuous.

quizActivities.question: Which question form is grammatically correct?
quizActivities.sentence: ____ by the time the semester ends?
options: Will you have finished your project
Will you have been finishing your project
Are you going to finish your project
quizActivities.correctAnswer: Will you have finished your project
quizActivities.hint: 'By the time' signals a deadline. Use Future Perfect (will have + past participle) for completion before that point.
quizActivities.explanation: Questions with Future Perfect follow: Will + subject + have + past participle. 'By the time' indicates completion before a future point.

quizActivities.question: Advanced: What's the most precise structure for this context?
quizActivities.sentence: He will be experienced in teaching because he ____ for 20 years by then.
quizActivities.hint: 'For 20 years' + explaining a future state (experienced). Future Perfect Continuous shows the duration causing the result.
quizActivities.explanation: While 'will have taught' is grammatically possible, 'will have been teaching' is more precise because it emphasizes the 20-year duration that causes his experience.

quizActivities.question: Identify the error in this sentence:
quizActivities.sentence: I'll call you when I will have ____ home.
quizActivities.hint: NEVER use 'will' in time clauses! After 'when', use present perfect 'have arrived', not future perfect.
quizActivities.explanation: The error is using 'will' in a time clause. Correct forms: 'when I arrive' or 'when I have arrived'—never 'will have arrived'.

quizActivities.question: Which form best emphasizes the result rather than the process?
quizActivities.sentence: By the end of the year, the company ____ 500 employees.
quizActivities.hint: The focus is on the countable result (500 employees hired), not the hiring process. Use Future Perfect for completion.
quizActivities.explanation: Both are grammatically possible, but 'will have hired' is best because it emphasizes the completed result (500 hires) rather than the ongoing process.

quizActivities.question: Complete the sequence with correct structures:
quizActivities.sentence: After she ____ her exam, she ____ the results, and by then she ____ for months.
options: has finished / will receive / will have been studying
will have finished / will receive / will have been studying
has finished / receives / will have been studying
quizActivities.correctAnswer: has finished / will receive / will have been studying
quizActivities.hint: Time clause after 'after' uses present perfect, main action uses future simple, and 'for months' needs Future Perfect Continuous.
quizActivities.explanation: This requires: Present Perfect (has finished) in the time clause, Future Simple (will receive) for the main action, and Future Perfect Continuous (will have been studying) for duration.

quizActivities.question: What negative form correctly shows something won't be completed?
quizActivities.sentence: By midnight, I ____ the report because it's too long.
quizActivities.hint: Negative Future Perfect uses 'won't have + past participle'. 'By midnight' signals a deadline for completion.
quizActivities.explanation: To form Future Perfect negative, use 'won't have + past participle'. This shows non-completion before a future deadline.

quizActivities.question: Which shows both forms mean almost the same in Future Perfect?
quizActivities.sentence: By 2025, we ____ this project.
options: will have completed / are going to have completed (both correct)
are going to have completed (only this)
quizActivities.correctAnswer: will have completed / are going to have completed (both correct)
quizActivities.hint: In Future Perfect, 'will have' and 'be going to have' are interchangeable with almost identical meanings.
quizActivities.explanation: Unlike other future tenses, Future Perfect allows both 'will have' and 'be going to have' with virtually the same meaning for completed actions.

quizActivities.question: What's the correct form in a conditional time clause?
quizActivities.sentence: She won't leave until she ____ the doctor.
quizActivities.hint: After 'until' (a time conjunction), use present perfect to show completion, never future tenses.
quizActivities.explanation: Time conjunctions like 'until' require present tenses. Present Perfect (has seen) shows the completed action, not 'will have seen'.

quizActivities.question: Which correctly shows the duration causing a future result?
quizActivities.sentence: They'll be exhausted because they ____ for 8 hours straight.
quizActivities.hint: To explain why they'll be exhausted (future state), show the continuous duration. Use Future Perfect Continuous.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous explains the cause of a future state. The 8-hour continuous work causes exhaustion, so use 'will have been working'.

quizActivities.question: What structure emphasizes achievement by a specific deadline?
quizActivities.sentence: By December, I ____ 1000 vocabulary words.
quizActivities.hint: 'By December' is a deadline. Counting achievements (1000 words) focuses on completion, not duration. Use Future Perfect.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Perfect emphasizes completion and countable results. '1000 words' is an achievement before the deadline 'by December', requiring 'will have learned'.

spellingActivities.sentence: We use Future ___ for finished actions.
For duration, we use Future Perfect ___.
The project ___ will be finished by Friday.
I’ll be completely ___ after the exam period.

spellingActivities.hint: Future Perfect Continuous can show ___ about future state
spellingActivities.sentence: His ___ is that he’ll be fluent by 2030.

spellingActivities.hint: Future Perfect is perfect for ___ and targets
spellingActivities.sentence: The report ___ is next Friday – I’ll have finished it by then.
